document.title: History and Social Science Standards of Learning for Virginia Public Schools

57B50A1895BA42E2AF6C4FB83DFE3DA2.description: evaluating the trade-offs in government decisions.

71C7A0EBAEFD478DAC252364C2D39E77.description:
describing how the Federal Reserve can use monetary policy to pursue price stability, full
employment, and economic growth with the goal of stabilizing the economy; and

BCA4B42571B247A4887B429FC91D8A0D.description: analyzing how Congress can use fiscal policy to stabilize the economy;

A668F9DAEE12432DAB8E4134171BAB29.description:
investigating and describing the types and purposes of taxation that are used by local, state,
and federal governments to pay for services provided by the government;

F60152A5952243989A3ADF7A5F9B9DD0.description:
describing the provision of government goods and services that are not readily produced by
the market;

FE5D80F7D54040EBA303B0A118481B08.description:
explaining government’s limited but important role in free enterprise and how that affects
individual economic freedoms;

88B790F78B274D1189541DFF97A03453.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to explain the role of
government in the Virginia and United States economies by

A96068008E3B43B7BDEB40AA536464E0.description: The Role of the Government in the Economy

A238B394D17544ABAA0DDB640498A2A4.description:
explaining how competition and free enterprise influence the local, national, and
global economies.

1AACA46AF85A44C693E47F145BFFFE87.description:
evaluating the factors that influence production and distribution of goods in a
market system; and

D444D62C6DEE40C9AFEBD344CFECC2F9.description:
explaining the differences between the principles of the Bill of Rights and the
Communist Manifesto;

C08447F8488A466F9538B81D31FDBEE7.description:
comparing and contrasting capitalism and socialism as economic systems,
including the role of government in each and individual economic freedoms;

529D991C73EF49BBB5BE22681636F505.description:
evaluating the economic and political systems of capitalism, communism,
Marxism, socialism, fascism, authoritarianism, and totalitarianism;

C880A74823F04BCEAE6AEF821283DA42.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to understand the role of the United
States in a changing world by

C7FDACC9DD3E45E1B5F48036CD4A4229.description:
examining the relationship of Virginia and the United States in the global economy,
including trends in international trade.

F382357BA4384363881E00BFEFB9E846.description:
assessing and analyzing the role of national interest in shaping foreign policy and
promoting world peace; and

FD976EC10CD24E198A457D2E85097105.description:
describing the responsibilities of the federal government for foreign policy and national
security;

17D85E16AF7F489380C9AFFAB2F35AD2.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to understand the role of the United
States in a changing world by

BD2999C3535D42D78AB08D273E4CA951.description: examining how civil liberties and civil rights are protected under the law.

37DD95244C634620906DA5468DD27E38.description: evaluating the balance between individual liberties and the public interest; and

8234C7E5B34A453C95A5D10EC8E7B0C8.description:
explaining how the Supreme Court has applied most of the protections of the Bill of Rights
to the states through a process of selective incorporation;

C5DC08F3465F4CFB871736759FA06267.description:
analyzing the rights of the accused and due process of law expressed in the Bill of Rights
and the Fourteenth Amendment;

7870D108505C441894B6F1BC0147335F.description: explaining the purpose of the Bill of Rights, with emphasis on First Amendment freedoms;

B950DCC9D5A841D89DA7844A43C3A2CB.description: explaining the difference between civil rights and civil liberties;

BE8EC3D339E645C28CFE43B496C91AC2.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to analyze civil liberties and civil rights
by

8C84B5717DA64D129E55121447C5DD38.description:
investigating and explaining the ways individuals and groups exert influence on state and
local governments.

686E52E36FC34E6E9F220BE3BC62BE16.description: comparing partisan and nonpartisan offices; and

F83985542F3244C7AB88BB1B6A87CA2D.description: analyzing the relationship between state and local governments and the roles of regional authorities, governing boards, and commissions;

44BD6E1A55944067AE0B7D4B6530041C.description: examining the structure and powers of local governments (county, city, and town);

A2A5B44134F74896B31386DDC2046177.description: explaining the law-making process at the state and local levels;

2086AA5B3DC4480D8467BA1B3562A0E2.description: analyzing legislative, executive, and judicial branches;

0C7CC537F6594160BDEEBFFD98FC6A87.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to explain the organization and powers
of the state and local governments as described in the Constitution of Virginia by

1A3B84CCB5F14D5AA746565027B2CEC8.description:
comparing the philosophy of originalism, judicial pragmatism, judicial activism, and
judicial restraint.

B48081931F9F497780B7B4EC4A15293E.description: describing how the Supreme Court decides cases; and

FA5BE88ABAFE49659C1C4A39A7EA9D4A.description:
explaining how the Marshall Court established the Supreme Court as an independent
branch of government in Marbury v. Madison;

CE2D705D8EB04A0C9B8250CE64615C6C.description: describing the organization, jurisdiction, and proceedings of federal courts;

9215CCDC657B4FC9A79D7FB86740E118.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to describe the scope and limits of the
powers of the federal judiciary as delineated in Article III of the United States Constitution by

83CAD9A1FEF646EE80E2250891FF684D.description:
comparing and contrasting executive branch processes with those of the legislative
branch.

BBAE3E35F4E14C6F92B760ABCFF76B48.description:
describing how the power of the executive branch has changed over time, including
the Twentieth, Twenty-second, and Twenty-fifth Amendments; and

82474C7763EF4EF298461E81A0C4E7D0.description: describing the structure and organization of the executive branch;

8BBC25ACDF2547E48A7EB7FE616D1F9C.description:
The student will apply history and science skills to describe the scope and limits of the
powers of the executive branch of the federal government as delineated in Article II of
the United States Constitution by

CA3C135B7C2A4720ABFCE2CC0220AA27.description:
evaluating how the processes of the legislative branch reflect the democratic
principles of American constitutional government.

E8C510E5E4284E62B43B59319A0754B8.description: describing how the power of the legislative branch has changed over time; and

8B3F57511E28410B83A8EBFEB73B6553.description: describing its structure and the process for the election of its members;

C720F9AD0026441CB317EDCD33AC3E24.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to describe the scope and limits
of the powers of the legislative branch of the federal government as delineated in
Article I of the United States Constitution by

FAC2BA8E8B144840BF4FF7E923FD5EDD.description: evaluating challenges of the election process, including redistricting and gerrymandering.

EFE9F2A3D4AA47F0B1CE1CCCC251D4FA.description:
explaining the role of the Electoral College and the impact of reapportionment and
redistricting on elections and governance; and

90F627E667894E899A4FF5957926BAA3.description:
analyzing the influence of media coverage, campaign advertising, public opinion polls,
social media, and digital communications;

A647537250C545F99BF185BC0EDDE034.description:
describing the nomination and election process, including the organization and evolving
role of political parties and interest groups;

B1C02E78A87F40FE8E3CECDBCD9DF7A3.description:
describing how amendments and laws have extended the right to vote to previously
disenfranchised Americans;

A93A88815DF44FD79A9F3B7EE0CA9B32.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to explain the process of local, state, and
national elections by

9E3D1BE8C9EE40B5A0DD0BE67F6A5AF6.description: understanding that the United States has a voluntary military and the importance of Selective Service registration.

540C0213DEB940578E9CCA2AFD7EB383.description: practicing personal and fiscal responsibility; and

36D2D8196F3F456090E27DDB463156A6.description: participating in the political process and voting in local, state, and national elections;

2D99A693A3204971803DB0A3AE39792D.description: obeying the law and paying taxes;

77F325FEB806409F9A789FCF5FCF67EA.description: describing the paths to U.S. citizenship;

04266246CF304E49B1DFF00C425FD6A5.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to explain the rights and responsibilities
of United States citizenship by

4A6AFFFF9CF94417944D2BE6EBFF4FC3.description:
evaluating how the U.S. Constitution and the Bill of Rights protect freedoms and limit
government.

428BDD98BCDD48E3A346E8FD0C1B30B3.description:
defining the meaning of the American Creed that calls on citizens to safeguard the liberty
of individual Americans within a unified nation, to respect the rule of law, and to
preserve the Constitution; and

52C53C31D1604632B95EA71C535C8A7C.description:
understanding the meaning and historical significance of the mottos "E Pluribus Unum"
and "In God We Trust";

07E9969BDD214C7284FB3AE25A5748F0.description: analyzing the five values of liberty, egalitarianism, individualism, populism, and laissezfaire government as described by Alexis de Tocqueville;

1A880140A5014847BCD51D3A03666B40.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to explore and understand the
significance, reverence, and pride around the foundation of the American republic by

1025BCE0053C41C5941A030ED185CAB8.description:
describing how the Bill of Rights affirms natural rights as something that precedes politics;
and

853B95B1178D430A88F1D44415950E41.description:
connecting the fundamental principles of checks and balances and separation of powers to
the three branches of government;

CA5FD878CB3140059EFA4A02C7B4D144.description:
examining the differences between the powers and authority of state and national
governments;

E430BEB8813043818CD0E115F6FC0A77.description:
defining the structure and authority of the national government as outlined in Article I,
Article II, and Article III;

15206A917AB84951B7BED8880F8AF49C.description: evaluating the purposes for government stated in the Preamble;

C74B26B3D9484A6A931F397A313F4DF2.description:
examining the ratification debates and The Federalist Papers, including but not limited to
No. 10 and No. 51;

9B162842D25544D3BAEE279DFC454FC8.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to analyze the Virginia and United
States Constitutions and the Bill of Rights by

1A0882682DA34D6FB3C91070966AFDA1.description: recognizing the freedom of the individual.

DBA8E516E6264CFF931FCCFA5C14F0E9.description: recognizing the necessity of compromise; and

CF0B06FBE2744651A6BFE200D79CD172.description: recognizing majority rule and minority rights;

07B4019695234CF48A5AFE98863580D4.description: recognizing the equality of all citizens under the law;

FAEFD39BBD5A484FBBBC3413800EB061.description: explaining the concepts of popular sovereignty, natural rights, the rule of law, selfgovernment, and “consent of the governed”;

3125D74405DD439F881F369AEE762A4F.description: The student will apply history and social science skills to describe the concept of democracy by

FF667211611740F8A39E1143947C8F16.description:
analyzing George Mason’s Virginia Declaration of Rights, Thomas Jefferson’s Virginia
Statute for Religious Freedom, and James Madison’s leadership role in securing adoption
of the Bill of Rights by the First Congress.

33F2D776D7E847A38F8353821BE7A453.description:
evaluating the foundational principles expressed in the Constitution of Virginia, the
Declaration of Independence, the Articles of Confederation, and the Constitution of the
United States; and

C39E3C06CDAF4A7BA6E245D535223C7E.description:
analyzing the foundational principles found in historic writings and prior governing
documents, including the Magna Carta, charters of the Virginia Company of London (April
10, 1606; May 23, 1609; and March 12, 1612), the works of Enlightenment philosophers
(Locke, Hobbes, Rousseau, and others), the Great Awakening, and the English Bill of
Rights;

BC367598970649E38BFD54754BB30C76.description:
describing the features of a democratic republic as influenced by forms of Athenian
democracy and the Roman Republic;

E53483C6A0C042488257B255BD6BBBCA.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to understand the foundations of
American constitutional government by

4C6923C7A7844777906FB9BB8A3F7D49.description:
contextualizing, corroborating, and evaluating sources for credibility, propaganda,
and bias to determine patterns and trends in Virginia and United States government
and politics.

6B0CC950DD554FA19369EFC72F54A645.description:
developing products that reflect an understanding of research and content to make
real-life connections; and

1B31487BA14241FC886125D95FC0601C.description:
engaging and communicating as an informed individual with persons with different
perspectives;

C232805D926540A9BC69B3A37643B75B.description:
using economic decision-making models to analyze and explain the incentives for
and consequences of a specific choice;

B358F97FAA58404EACB1A67D99F91A6A.description: determining cause and effect to analyze connections;

52ED7320DAA34A56AF356CC1F204F493.description:
comparing and contrasting historical, cultural, economic, and political
perspectives;

F53D46F55E3F408AB06DFDBE6D774D9A.description:
investigating and analyzing evidence from multiple sources to construct arguments
and draw conclusions;

F88DDD45DF5F42EC9AFBCB14E5787B8A.description:
questioning and using inquiry to construct arguments, using evidence from
multiple sources;

D2A73930FDB94FC3967F03D653743A51.description: applying geographic skills to determine and/or predict patterns and trends;

ECF34E9CCBD84695A7A629353D99DAE4.description: The student will apply history and social science skills to the content by
